Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2008 07:18AM Urbie wrote: If she doesn't have clear margins they should definitely go back and remove more tissue.  And if that means a mastectomy, then that is what needs to be done.  My stepmother did not have clear margins when she had a lumpectomy years ago and her doctor said that the radiation would take care of those remaining cancer cells.   The cancer returned and spread and she died almost three years ago.  All of the cells need to be removed or they will spread.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy and Negative Margins stang Route53

Posts.Content: May 15, 2008 06:23AM Urbie wrote: Well my heart goes out to all three of you, and to the many "just diagnosed" folks out there.  As others have said, you are all at the absolute worst part right now.  I was diagnosed July 26 2007, had bilateral mastectomy (mostly for peace of mind) with immediate reconstruction (tissue expanders placed at time of surgery).  I started chemo (4 tx Taxotere/Cytoxan) in early October and going in for my first hair cut today!  I too have two small children (6 & 8) and the whole experience was very hard, but at the end of the day, I feel I am a better person for having gone through it.  And I KNOW that I am a better mother to my children.  Every day is precious and I know that now.  It is a hard road to travel, but if you stay strong and fight to win, I believe that you will.  My prayers to you all.
Posts.Title: just found out! tammyj38 Kerry71

Posts.Content: Urbie wrote: Hi - new here... I found this website and thought that this would be good for me. I went in for a routine mammogram (only my second one because I am 40 years old) and they called me back for another look. Long story short is that a biopsy determined that I have IDC and quite a bit of DCIS in my right breast. I went through ALL of the tests and it doesn't appear to have spread, but I have decided to have a bilateral mastectomy on August 16 and to have reconstruction start the same day. I can't seem to find out much about recovery time for the surgery. How long will it be until I can get back to my life? And even with bilateral surgery, will I always be afraid of it coming back? Dx 7/26/2007, IDC, 2cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Diagnosed two weeks ago Urbie determinedmom

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2007 06:20AM Urbie wrote: Thank you Barbara. It really does feel like a very irritating, sore skin sensitivity as wearing clothing really is uncomfortable. I am encouraged by your three week comment! I can live with it, but I really would love to look forward to when it will subside. I have an appointment with my ps on Tuesday and I will check with him on it. I also plan to look into a physical therapist to help with this and getting my arm strength and movement back. I went to the grocery store today with my daughters (5&8) and they had to steer the cart because I couldn't. They thought it was great fun! Closing the hatchback on the back of my car is really hard too. The things you take for granted...
Posts.Title: Post surgery NERVE PAIN seacat mjm1

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2007 06:00PM Urbie wrote: Tammy, just to let you know, a month ago I posted on this thread about the nerve pain that I was experiencing after my surgery and now mine is gone.  I feel great and I can sleep on my sides again and have really no pain associated with my surgery at all.  I wanted you to know that it does subside, or at least it has for me.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Post surgery NERVE PAIN seacat mjm1

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2007 06:38AM Urbie wrote: I am two weeks out from my bilateral mastectomy and feel pretty good except for the constant feeling that I have the chills from a bad sunburn all across my chest and through my back. It feels like sore skin from the flu, only worse. I was figuring that it is the nerves coming back to life and that it would pass soon enough but after reading these posts I wonder if that is true. I have been taking lots of Advil but that doesn't seem to help. What should I do??? Should I call my surgeon?

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2007 08:40AM - edited Oct 2, 2007 08:40AM by Urbie Hi Janice, I opted for no port because of only 4 tx, and they said that the first day and the "vein problems" were probably caused by stress.  Next time I will take an Ativan before I go in and then maybe the first bag with the Ativan & benedryl will make me sleep.  I woke up at 2:30 in the morning before my tx and still wasn't able to take a nap even with the meds!  Although it was a pretty chatty bunch socializing, snacking and the massage therapist went from person to person.  Nice place - Martha Jefferson Hospital is...  Have a great day everyone.  I am off to get the Nuelasta shot and I read somewhere here to get it in my abdomen.  Another new experience for me...
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2007 04:20PM Urbie wrote: Marietta, I really feel your pain with your son.  My 8 year old daughter literally went off the deep end when I was diagnosed.  Her Grandma (my step mother) died two years ago from breast cancer and in her mind, that meant that Mommy was going to die too.  IT WAS AWFUL, AWFUL, AWFUL.   I was trying to deal with the whole thing myself and she went into obsessive, compulsive mode and was washing her hands constantly and not eating because the food touched the plate...  She lost 6 pounds and she started out at only 52 pounds to begin with.  She would cry for an hour at a time, uncontrolably, several times a day.  I took her to a therapist, which didn't really help and then two days before my surgery I took her to see our family doctor and requested that he put her on an anti-depressent.  He put her on a low dose of Prozac and I will tell you that it saved our lives.  She stopped crying, washing and freaking out and she was able to accept the fact that mommy had to have an operation, chemo and then she would be fine.  She has always been a "high anxiety" child so it shouldn't have come as such a big surprise that maybe her brain wasn't producing something that it needed to be happy.  It has made her a happy, more confident, more outgoing, delightful child.  All of our family, who has known her to be quiet, reserved and hardly every smiling, can see a huge difference.  This BC thing just was too much for her to take in.  I have never been an advocate of medicating children, unless it is really necessary for their quality of life.  Prozac saved her.    This is big stuff for kids to handle.  Just thought I would share my story.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2007 05:39PM Urbie wrote: Well it has been a wonderful weekend and the Packers pulled it off and beat the Redskins, ugly... but a win none the less.  I have been so "OK" about my the idea of my hair falling out that I almost thought that maybe it wouldn't, just because of murphy's law and all.  I was wrong.  It officially started coming out in much more than normal amounts in a brush today.  I made a big pile on the counter.  I guess that I will have to make the head shaving appointment for early this week.  I am ready and I am really a "bring it on" kind of girl so let's get on with it.  At least my taste buds are back in check and I was able to enjoy the wine tasting yesterday at the Wine & Garlic Festival.  I bought a T-shirt that says....  "Wine is a constant reminder that God loves us and loves us to be happy".  I usually never buy things like this for myself, but I buy them for others.  Not this time, it is for me.   Paxton, I hope you are feeling better.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2007 06:06AM Urbie wrote: Hi Ladies - today will be a very busy day for me as my husband and I are hosting our dinner party group tonight.  On the menu...   spinach balls, fresh salsa and hot crab dib for Apps. Dinner - My famous BBQ ribs, twice baked potatoes, spinach & artichoke vegtabele casserole and salad with toasted almonds, cranberry's, bacon & blue cheese w/lemon olive oil & black currant vinegar dressing.  And then cherry pie for dessert - pie is in the oven now!  I have been cooking for two days and today I get to clean the house.  It is a great group of people and we all love to drink red wine.   Trigeek, does that count as hydrating??  I will be very careful how much wine I drink as I cannot go into my chemo on Monday with a hangover...  that would be awful.   Have a great weekend all!   And Ulla, we have not forgotten you at all.  Our prayers are with you everyday.

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2007 07:00AM Urbie wrote: Hi all - TX #2 was Monday and I am feeling very tired and a bit fluish, but nothing too terrible.  I had to go all the way with the hair last night and my DH shaved it with a razor.  It was falling out all over; in my eyes, mouth and all over my clothes...  just had to go.  I was kind of weepy about it, which I don't really understand except that I get that way when I am really tired.  Now I am really bald, but no major tragedy...   A much bigger concern is that I have no taste buds at all.  I lost some on Tx #1 but nothing like this.  I can smell, but no taste.  Any advice on things that I may be able to actually taste???  I guess I won't have to worry about sneaking into my kids halloween candy this year...

My insurance finally said that they would cover a wig from a "wig store" instead of a "durable medical supply store".  What a pain in the ass this whole thing has been....  So I went down to the wig store and bought the wig, but I will need to have it cut and styled very soon.  My hair is coming out very rapidly and my kids think that it is funny to grab a handful and see what happens.  I don't think that it is as funny as they do...   I also found out today that I was accepted into the assisatance program for the Emend drug, because my insurance won't cover it.  Yeah!!!  I was so afraid to go to tx #2 without it.  They will send it to me at no charge for each of my next three tx's.  I will say a prayer of thanx for Merck Pharmeceulticals.   I am sorry to hear you are still feeling bad Paxton.  I will say an extra prayer for you tonight.

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2007 05:41PM Urbie wrote: Hi Ladies - sorry that I have been "absent" for awhile but I have been so busy.  My husband and I own a retail shop and from Thanksgiving to Christmas it is insane, which we love but have to get through.   I make gift baskets by the dozen and I also have another job (and two kids) too.  Busy, busy, busy...  Thanksgiving was great and I ate a lot.  I was careful all last week though because of the chemo tx weigh in tomorrow!  I refuse to gain weight because of this whole thing and I am holding fast.  Down ten pounds from diagnosis day and I really want to keep it off.  So many more outfits to chose from!!!  Makes getting dressed so much more fun.  Tomorrow is my last tx and I am sooooo excited!  And I am counting the days to my exchange surgery on December 21 (18 and counting).  It will be a Merry Christmas for me!   Sorry to hear about the snow Paxton.  We lived in Minnesota for five years - Twin Cities - loved it, but HATED the weather.  50's and sunny here today ~ winter in Virginia.   We will get snow, but it melts in a day or two.  My kind of winter.    Hope you all are well!!!!

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2007 07:07PM - edited Oct 1, 2007 07:07PM by Urbie Well my first chemo session is behind me!  And it went really pretty well.  The only problem was finding a vein that would work.  First one had a valve that wouldn't open, second one collapsed because I flinched and held my breath, third one was working fine but I got up to go to the bathroom and the bag was empty (small one Ativan & Benedryl) and the blood got sucked up into the tube.  It clotted before they could flush it so they needed to go to vein number 4.  They served snacks, tea and lunch!  And I even got my feet massaged!  It was actually a nice morning and I am still feeling fine.  I know that it is wishful thinking that it will last, but one can hope. Paxton - they told me today that if I have diarrhea to take Imodium AD - take 2 tabs after 1st liquid stool than 1 tab every hour if still having liquid stools, for up to 12 hours.  If no relief after 12 hours to call the doctor.  Seems like a lot of Imodium, but that is what they told me.   I go in tomorrow morning for a Neulasta shot - they say that my insurance approved it, which I cannot believe because I have no coverage for brand name perscriptions.  But maybe because it will be administered in the hospital it falls under some other category??  I am just hoping that I can get more of this Emend because today went fine. Karyll - are you still feeling good?   Have a good night all!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2007 04:22PM - edited Oct 7, 2007 04:22PM by Urbie (favorite meal as a kid!)  I can remember now.. Venison & Popperoni  (couldn't say macaroni as a child) 2 lbs. cut up venison/stew meat 2 capfuls Kitchen Bouquet One 8oz Tomato sauce One can Campbell's beef Consume Soup One lg. can drained, peeled tomatoes (I use chopped) 2 tsp lemon juice 1 Tbs brown sugar 1 tsp minced garlic 1 tsp marjoram Corn starch & water Cut off all fat & gristle on stew meat and brown w/2 capfuls of Kitchen Bouquet.  Put browned meat and juices into crock pot.  Add all ingredients except for the corn starch and water.  Cook all day on low in crock pot or in oven casserole dish at 350 degrees for 2 hours.  Dissolve about 1 Tbs of corn starch in water and add to sauce to thicken.  Serve over spiral noodles tossed in parmesan cheese and parsley.  Serve with Popovers for yummy dinner!

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2007 07:16PM Urbie wrote: Marietta - I had the shot in my stomach and I only had the bone/joint pain from the waist down.  I don't know if it has anything to do with where you get the shot, but I didn't have any neck or back pain.  I felt the achy hips and knees but took tylenol for it and it wasn't terrible.  It seemed to help to keep my legs active - running or walking made me feel better.  I will do the next ones in my stomach too.  It didn't hurt much at all.  Good luck!

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2007 09:13AM Urbie wrote: Hi Cheryll - I have had LOTS of eye problems that I have been told are from the Taxotere.  Chemo apparently clogs your tear ducts so the excess tears don't have anywere to go but down your face.  I cannot wear my contacts at all anymore - too much redness, burning and pain, and thus - tearing.  I just had TX #3 yesterday and they say it won't cause long term damage.  An eye doctor friend of mine suggested "It should resolve after your treatments and your tear glands recover.  They will recover.  However during your treatment you need to keep your eyes very well lubricated.  When you resume treatment start a tear supplement such as genteal gel every 1-2 hours or optive tears.  If this is not helping use refresh pm ointment every 1-2 hrs and use refresh pm at nite always.  The ointment is hard to put in.  The best way to put it in is to keep it warm in your pocket.  Then pull down the lower lid and put 1/4 inch of ointment in.  Also start omega 3 at least 1000 mg a day." He is good and I trust his judgement.  He lives about a 1000 miles away from me or I would go see him!  So about one and a half more months of sore eyes and then onto the new year!  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2007 08:10AM - edited Oct 4, 2007 08:10AM by Urbie Hi Ladies, I have been keeping up on your posts, but haven't had much to say.  I hope you are all doing better.  Three days out from Tx one and feel tired and nauseated, but it won't kill me.  And now my period decides to show up!  Add that to the mix... I have a hard time imagining diarreah, I have the opposite problem and it is not good.   My daughter was home sick from school yesterday with a fever so we layed around most of the day and napped.  I am taking the anit-nausea drugs and they are making me tired and foggy brained.  I miss my coffee in the morning....

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2007 04:20PM - edited Oct 7, 2007 04:20PM by Urbie Hi Ladies,  I am so happy to report that I have had a really good day today!  I walked my usual 3 miles this morning (couldn't do that the last couple of days) and took my kids on a picnic lunch and then took them to decorate pumpkins at Michael's.  My kids were SO happy to have mommy back for the day (two girls 5 & 8).  I was getting so depressed yesterday (sounds like that was the way it was for everyone) thinking that I was going to feel crappy for 12 weeks.  Today was six days after tx-1 for me so there is hope that the next two weeks will be good!  I hope that the next treatments give me only six days of yuck too.  Next time though I will take stomach meds before the treatment to avoid this painful tummy.   Hopfully I can stay up late to see the Packers vs. Bears (longtime Packer fan - grew up in Green Bay).   And -  I have a recipe to share with you Moose and Venison folks (can use stew meat too).  This is so good.  I will try to put it in a separate post...

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2007 03:39PM - edited Oct 8, 2007 03:39PM by Urbie Oh, I forgot the big gun that I cannot afford!  The Emend I also took the day of, and two days after.  I do think that it made a big difference and I hope that they approve me for assisatance.  If not, I will have to sell one of my kids And on a good note, I had my white counts checked today and they were 9.2!  Yeah Nuelasta!  I will take the bone pain and smile (with meds) all the way to my ps office tomorrow for a fill in my tissue expanders!!  After tomorrow, I will officially have a bust they may take notice in the right shirt.     Have a great night all...

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2007 03:34PM - edited Oct 29, 2007 03:36PM by Urbie Hi all - I am back in the land of the living!  Man, feeling sick makes you appreciate feeling better.  I am over most of the SE's except for this damn diarreaha.  My stomach feels so tender and I am a week past #2.  My taste buds are coming back and I have had a few pieces of chocolate today.  My "chemo angel" sent me a wonderful, big bowl of halloween candy with all sorts of plastic kid stuff for my kids.  It sure put a smile on my face.   The world is full of wonderful, caring people. And, big news today....  I decided today that I am going to do the 3-day breast cancer walk in Boston next year.  I am so excited and I just may organize a team here in Charlottesville to go to the walk and raise lots of money for the Cure.  A good friend of mine who lived in Boston for years is going to go too.  60 miles in 3 days....  I can't wait.      Anyone want to go?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2007 10:59AM - edited Oct 5, 2007 10:59AM by Urbie I am still here, but because my brain is so fuzzy I cannot remember any of my childhood.  I read these posts last night and for the life of me cannot remember my lunchbox or any toys.  I don't know if it is the chemo or the anti-nausea drugs, but I am very spacy.  I am supposed to go pick up my wig today, but I don't think driving is a good idea.  My tx was Monday, when will I be able to stop taking anti-nausea stuff so I can think straight?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2007 03:02PM - edited Oct 5, 2007 03:02PM by Urbie Paxton, the idea of even being in a 100 mile radius of someone cutting up a moose right now would kill me.  My husband deer hunts and I like the venision, but the cutting up part is more than I can stand to think about.  Even taking a fish hook out of a fish is too much for me , even with no chemo stomach!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2007 07:21AM - edited Oct 6, 2007 07:21AM by Urbie Hi - I had a very bad experience last night.  I will say that I have always had a weak stomach and have taken medication in the past for acid stomach problems but this was pretty bad.  I was feeling pretty good so I decided to have a beer while making homemade pizza for the family. I drank about half of it and my stomach started hurting so badly that I was on the floor in tears.  My daughter came in and found me on the floor and my husband got home from work and I was in so much pain that I couldn't get up.  We paged my onc and it turned out to be very bad gas up under my ribs and stomach.  It was a long hour until we got it under control with Prilosec and GasX ~ and finally Ativan.  The only thing that I had in my stomach was a fruit smoothy that I made for my kids after school so the fruit and the beer made a really bad combo on my stomach.  Someone told me to have a beer because wine tastes so bad....  Never again.  My onc says no more fruit smoothies either and I will listen because I don't want to go through that again.  And I didn't get to eat the pizza either!  My kids and DH said it was good.  I got Saltines...
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2007 03:34PM - edited Oct 8, 2007 03:34PM by Urbie Hi Cheryl, I have taken so many meds for tx one it is hard to keep them straight, but I will try.   The day before - 2 decadron am & pm, day of - they gave me benedryl, ativan, decadron then TC.  Day after - decadron am & pm, zofran in am and then compazine if any break thru nausea and then ativan if any more break thru nausea.  I should have taken something like Nexium before my tx because I had terrible stomach pain.  I am now taking prilosec otc every 12 hours (plus tums & gas x), but will get a scrip for Nexium for tx 2-4.   I am also taking advil & tylenol for the bone pain caused by the Nuelasta shot.   I feel like a f******* pharmacy!  When I walked into my first doctors appointment at diagnosis I didn't have to list ONE medication that I was taking.  Now, when I go to my ps tomorrow I will need two pages to list them all.   Ahh, cancer keeps the pharmaceutical companies in business.  Why would they want to see a cure?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2007 01:22PM Urbie wrote: Marietta - I am also reading The Glass Castle.  It is really good.  I have a stack of books to read and found that they week after chemo I couldn't even read!  I was too spacey and kept falling asleep.   And, a friend of mine has a clippers that I can borrow today to have the "very, very, very short hair cut party" tonight.   My kids are excited and really looking forward to it.  It is better to include them and make it fun, instead of a sad thing that mommie is losing her hair.  I will post a picture, but I don't know how!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2007 12:19PM Urbie wrote: Karyll - I have finished 3 of 4 Taxotere/Cytoxan and the eye issues have been the worst side effect for me.  In hind sight, I would use the natural tears eye drops 4 to 6 times per day and the Refresh PM eye ointment at night before the burning eyes happens.  And, if you wear contact lenses, I would avoid wearing them during taxotere txs.  Although, I seem to one of the few to have this problem...  AND, I am hungry, but I cannot taste anything!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in September?? where are you ladies Methusala StillKicking

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2007 07:37AM - edited Sep 27, 2007 07:37AM by Urbie Hi amyrlcsw - I too scored a 15 on the Oncotype DX.  I met with my onc last Friday for the first time and walked in to his office fully convinced that I didn't need chemo with that score.  He explained the "gray area" to me and he told me that he couldn't tell me what to do.  He said that I had to follow my gut.   After much consideration and talking with my husband, I have decided to do the chemo.  I have two young children and I feel that I have to do everything in my power to make sure that this doesn't ever come back.  I know that there are no guartentees, but at least I can say that I did everything that I could.  My 4 treatments of Taxotere/Cytoxan start on Monday.  12 weeks of who knows, for a long lifetime to see my girls grow up.  Tough decision, but I feel confident that I have made the right one.  Best of luck with your decision!
Posts.Title: Oncotype Dx test... Harley44 123JustMe

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2007 05:16AM Urbie wrote: Hi - I just checking in with the October girls.  I started 4 tx of TX on Oct. 1 and had kind of a yucky week, but I felt back to normal (other than stomach issues) by Sunday.  I was SO relieved to have the yuck feeling for only a week and then I can live with two good weeks before tx #2.  I still have my hair, but figure I only have a few more days left.  I have a couple of wigs that I really like and just ordered a "halo" for my Tilley hat and a "fall" to wear with my baseball cap for exercising.  I just don't know if I can do the turban thing outside of the house.  It just says cancer to me and I don't have it anymore... (since my bilateral :o)   Good wishes and prayers to you all!!!!
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2007 10:16AM Urbie wrote: Well my husband did the buzz cut for me tonight and my girls took picutures of him cutting my hair in a lawn chair out on the lawn!  It was actually kind of fun.  Now my hair is about 1/8 to 1/4" and I really like it.  I wish it would just stay this way and not fall all of the way out...   And Debkay, all the rest of the hair on my body is falling out too (if you know what I mean) and I figure that I would just see how that goes...  Prayers...
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2007 05:02AM Urbie wrote: Trisha - I also am puzzled by the "9" score for aggressivness of a tumor.  If you are ER- and PR- then you wouldn't have had an Oncotype test, which is a recurrence score between 1-100 and if that was the test, a 9 would be a good score not a bad one.  So I would ask your Oncologist to explain this to you.  And I was just like you, young and have two kids at home (5&8) and I was scared of chemo too.  I had a bilateral mastectomy because I wanted to be as aggressvie as I could and I thought that was enough but my oncologist said that he thought I should do chemo becasue I had so much life left to live and that I should do everything I could to make that possible.  So I did the chemo and I am halfway done and I am glad that I did it.  Some of the side effects suck, but this too shall pass.  I will go into 2008 knowing that I did everything that I could to prevent this cancer from growing in my body.  I need to see my babies grow up and feeling like I have the flu for a week every three weeks for that, is a small price to pay.  I do know that chemo won't give me any guarentees, but at least it is fighting with the biggest gun I can find and that is all that I can do.  At the end of the day, you have to follow what your heart tells you to do.  Good luck with the decision.   Oh, and I never had a port put in because I figured for four treatments they could just go into a vein.  That has worked fine - as long as I relax (Ativan) before they stick me!
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2007 09:08PM - edited Oct 1, 2007 09:08PM by Urbie Well my first chemo session is behind me!  And it went really pretty well.  The only problem was finding a vein that would work.  First one had a valve that wouldn't open, second one collapsed because I flinched and held my breath, third one was working fine but I got up to go to the bathroom and the bag was empty (small one Ativan & Benedryl) and the blood got sucked up into the tube.  It clotted before they could flush it so they needed to go to vein number 4.  They served snacks, tea and lunch!  And I even got my feet massaged!  It was actually a nice morning and I am still feeling fine.  I know that it is wishful thinking that it will last, but one can hope. I go in tomorrow morning for a Neulasta shot - they say that my insurance approved it, which I cannot believe because I have no coverage for brand name perscriptions.  But maybe because it will be administered in the hospital it falls under some other category??  Now my challenge tomorrow is to convince my ps to squeeze me in for a fill in my tissue expanders.  They say I have about 7 days until my white count drops so it shouldn't be a problem (theoretically).  I may have to beg....  I want this reconstruction and exchange done by the end of the year!  New boobs for Christmas :o)   Goodnight all and I hope you are all feeling good.
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2007 08:57AM Urbie wrote: Alishar and Kara,  I am also on the same schedule as you two.  First tx on Oct. 1 and 2nd on Oct. 22.   I am also losing lots of hair, started yesterday,  and planing the shave soon.  I am not freaked out by being bald, BUT THE SHAVE IS SUCH A BIG STEP!!!   I just need to call my hair dresser and go there....  I'm with you ladies!!
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2007 12:58AM - edited Oct 6, 2007 12:58AM by Urbie Alishar - I too was experiencing the constipation problem and now it has turned the other way...  I still feel like I have the flu (sore body and nausea) and I hope that I feel better tomorrow so I can do some things while my kids are off of school.  I don't think a hike in the mountains is going to happen, but a picnic near the lake perhaps. And the question on the coffee and red wine is....  does this non-interest last the entire length of chemo?  or possibly just the first week or so after?   Twelve weeks with no wine or coffee is hard to even imagine...       Have a good weekend all!
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2008 08:03AM - edited Apr 25, 2008 08:04AM by Urbie Wow - oncologists certainly are different.  I walked into my onc's office last September with an oncotype score of 15 convinced that I didn't need to do chemo and he thought that I should.  I was 40 years old with two young children and wanted to do everything that I could do to keep this cancer from coming back.  After a weekend of discussion with my husband and family, I decided to "just do it" and I am SO glad that I did.  I had a 2cm IDC with no node involvement and yet I chose a bilateral mastectomy so it only made sense to me to keep being aggresive.  Now, I can go on with my life knowing that I did EVERYTHING that I possibly could.  And, in my opinion, the chemo really wasn't that bad - worth it in the end for me.  It gives me peace of mind...  Good luck with your decision.
Posts.Title: Oncotype not what the onc predicted lanihardage lanihardage

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2008 03:57PM Urbie wrote: I looked at the Oncotype DX website today and their graph says that any score over 25 will benefit from chemo.  Just an FYI...
Posts.Title: Oncotype not what the onc predicted lanihardage lanihardage

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2007 07:28PM - edited Oct 3, 2007 07:28PM by Urbie Karyll - I am starting day three after my first tx on Monday and I feel like I have a case of the stomach flu.  I took my last Emend and having a ginger ale (at 5:30) in the morning!  I have no desire to drink red wine (tasted horrible on day one) and now no desire for coffee.  Chemo really changes some things.  I had the Nuelasta shot in my stomach yesterday and it was no big deal, but most of the day my stomach was crampy so I went for a walk and then layed down most of the day.  My DH took the kids to McDonalds and shopping to get them out of the house.  Funny how Mommy going thru Chemo isn't enough to keep a 5 year old from screaming and crying about cleaning up her room...  My 8 year old played doctor and brought me water and peanuts to munch on. I am using Crest Pro-health toothpaste and Biotene mouth wash regularly so I hopefully can steer clear of the mouth issues.  Only time will tell.  Day by Day it seems, but I can't complaine too much compared to some of you.  Keep your eyes on the finish line ~ it will be worth it.   Good days to you all.
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2007 09:20PM Urbie wrote: My Emend story is that I went to fill five perscriptions prior to chemo #1 and the cost of the Emend one was $315.  I do not have any ins. coverage for brand name drugs and it doesn't come in a generic.  I talked to my onc office to see if they had any samples and they had one three pack available for me to take.  I then started the process with the patient advocate at the hospital to see if I would qualify to get the drug at no cost.  I filled out some paperwork, made a bunch of phone calls and had to clear up mis-information given by my insurance company and then was approved yesterday.  They will ship me the pills via UPS for the next three tx's.  I was SO relieved because I had nausea starting only the day after I finished the Emend.   It is my understanding that you will qualify if your insurance does not cover it and you have a household income of less than $80,000 (for a family of four). I felt VERY drugged and spacey from the anti-nausea drugs.  Made me wonder why they don't warn you not to drive.  I wasn't sure if I would actually get to where I was trying to get to!
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2007 08:36PM - edited Sep 27, 2007 08:36PM by Urbie Hi Eve - I am so happy to hear that you are doing well with the TC treatment.  I found out today that my insurance won't cover the Emend and I hope they can find something more affordable that will work.  Did you use Emend?

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2007 11:14PM Urbie wrote: Hi all, my second tx went well - hit a good vein on the first try!  This time I got a hand and arm massage to relax me before my tx.   I came home feeling very, very tired and my DH picked up the girls from school and kept them at work and took them to dinner.  He did homework with them and put then to bed so I could just rest.  Gotta love a good man.   I am off to get the Neulasta shot!   Alishar and Kara, I hope you are feeling well today too...  Good to be halfway done!
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2007 06:28AM Urbie wrote: Hi Ladies - I too am back from my chemo "sick week" and am starting to feel much better.  I have not had any constipation this time, only the opposite and it isn't getting any better.  I was out for my walk today and almost didn't make it home to the bathroom!  That would have been very, very bad...  My tummy is very sore and it is one week past #2, but other than that, things are getting better.   Now I can say that I am halfway done!   Ulla, I am praying for you.

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2007 07:31PM - edited Sep 30, 2007 07:31PM by Urbie Hi Ladies - I start tomorrow, 8:30 am.  4 treatments of TC - every three weeks.  I am having wine and lasagna (with candles) with my husband tonight.  It will be a long 12 weeks.  Prayers to you all.

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2007 08:09AM - edited Oct 2, 2007 08:09AM by Urbie Hi Karen, They talked to me about a port, but I opted "no" because I only have to do 4 treatments and didn't want any more procedures that will cause me pain and leave a scar.  She said that the subsequent TXs they shouldn't have so much trouble with my veins - first time nerves...

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2007 06:24AM Urbie wrote: Ulla, I cannot imagine how much harder bc would be if I had lost a baby too.  I lost two babies over the years and it is very hard, but at the same time as a bc diagnosis....  You have the right feeling that the baby was an angel sent to save your life.  My hair officially started coming out in small handfuls yesterday.  I will have to make the head shaving appointment for early this week or my shower drain will get very clogged.  I am actually interested to see how I look bald.  I have one more good week before Chemo tx #2.  Still praying that the Emend folks will approve me for free Emend.  I am scared to death to do it without, but I will have to try if they don't approve me.   Have a great week ladies.

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2007 02:17PM Urbie wrote: Mamhop - I scored a 15 on the Oncotype and chose to do the chemo and have finished 3 of the four Taxotere/Cytoxan treatments.  In my opinion, it is totally worth it and not that bad.  The side effects are annoying but doable and even being bald isn't so bad.  Hair grows back, but my kids only have one mom.   I couldn't take the risk and not do it.   Good luck!
Posts.Title: Oncotype Dx test... Harley44 123JustMe

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2008 12:05PM Urbie wrote: When I think back to six months ago (where you are now in this process) I just remember how absolutely terrified I was.  Going in for that bone scan, MRI and CT scan was the worst day of my life.  Now, six months later, after a bilateral mastectomy, reconstruction and chemo, I am doing great.  You will get though this, and all of us here now how hard it is, but you will.  Try to stay as positive as possible and be thankful that this was caught at an early stage.  And, my bc was found in a routine mammo (at 40 years old) and the IDC turned out to be just under 2cm, but the MRI showed DCIS throughout much of my right breast.  I chose the bilateral and know that I did the right thing - no regrets here.  You will be in my prayers Goldie!!!
Posts.Title: Anyone have DCIS AND invasive ductal carcinoma? Goldie Sassa
